title-group.article-title: Perspectives of Physicians and Nurses Regarding End-of-Life Care in the Intensive Care Unit

article-meta.aff: 1Critical Care Medicine, Mayo Clinic, Jacksonville, FL, USA
2Divisions of Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine and Internal Medicine, Mayo Clinic, Rochester, MN, USA

author-notes.corresp: Emir Festic, 4500 San Pablo Road, Jacksonville, FL 32224, USA. Email: festic.emir@mayo.edu

abstract.p: Context: The delivery of end-of-life care (EOLC) in the intensive care unit (ICU) varies widely among medical care providers. The differing opinions of nurses and physicians regarding EOLC may help identify areas of improvement. Objective: To explore the differences of physicians and nurses on EOLC in the ICU and how these differences vary according to self-reported proficiency level and primary work unit. Design: Cross-sectional survey of 69 ICU physicians and 629 ICU nurses. Setting: Single tertiary care academic medical institution. Results: A total of 50 physicians (72%) and 331 nurses (53%) participated in the survey. Significant differences between physicians and nurses were noted in the following areas: ability to safely raise concerns, do not resuscitate (DNR) decision making, discussion of health care directives, timely hospice referral, spiritual assessment documentation, utilization of social services, and the availability of EOLC education. In every domain of EOLC, physicians reported a more positive perception than nurses. Additional differences were noted among physicians based on experience, as well as among nurses based on their primary work unit and self-reported proficiency level. Conclusions: Even with an increased focus on improving EOLC, significant differences continue to exist between the perspectives of nurses and physicians, as well as physicians among themselves and nurses among themselves. These differences may represent significant barriers toward providing comprehensive, consistent, and coordinated EOLC in the ICU.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Twenty percent of Americans die in the intensive care unit (ICU).1 Thus, competency in providing end-of-life care (EOLC) is an essential skill for ICU providers. Optimal EOLC requires the diverse perspectives of various members of the medical team.2 Indeed, the successful implementation of EOLC requires deliberation, leadership, and explicit collaboration.3–6 Although they are part of the same care team and profess the same overall goal, nurses and physicians have differing views of EOLC in the ICU.7–12 Additionally, when studied separately, both nurses and physicians exhibit considerable variability among themselves.13–18 These differences in perspective may represent significant opportunities to provide comprehensive, consistent, and coordinated EOLC in the ICU.

Decision-making processes regarding withholding and withdrawing life-sustaining treatments among French critical care nurses and physicians were perceived as satisfactory by 73% of physicians and 33% of nurses.9 More than 90% of medical providers believed that decision making should be collaborative, but 50% of physicians and only 27% of nurses believed that the nursing staff was actually involved. Moreover, it has been argued that the perceptions of nurses, rather than physicians, may be a more reliable indicator of the quality of medical decision-making processes.9

The identification of opinions of medical care providers is a central endpoint to measure the quality of EOLC.19 The presence of divergent opinions between team members has been associated with poor outcomes for patients, families, nurses, and physicians.20,21 In order to explore the differences in perspectives of physicians and nurses on EOLC in the ICU at our tertiary care academic medical institution, we conducted a survey of critical care physicians, fellows, and nurses. We additionally sought to investigate how nursing perspectives were influenced by self-reported proficiency level and primary work unit (medical ICU, surgical ICU, or medical−surgical ICU).

sec.title: Study Design and Participants
sec.p: This study was a cross-sectional survey of all critical care physicians (attending staff and fellows) and nurses at a tertiary academic medical center in Rochester, Minnesota. Critical care physicians, attendings and fellows, are of internal medicine and anesthesia background. Medical ICU is primarily staffed with intensivists with background in internal medicine and surgical ICU with intensivists with background in anesthesia. Mixed, medical–surgical ICU, is staffed by both internal medicine and anesthesia-trained intensivists, on equal share basis. All critical care units at this center operate as “closed” units. The Mayo Clinic Institutional Review Board approved the study.

sec.title: Survey Development and Content
sec.p: The survey instrument was developed by modifying a preexisting survey on EOLC in the ICU (Douglas M, Wheaton Franciscan Health Care, Inc, unpublished, used with permission) with additional statements. The survey instrument was pretested for content validity by a sample of non-ICU physicians and nurses familiar with providing EOLC.

The survey contained 12 fixed-response statements using a 5-point Likert scale (1, strongly disagree; 2, disagree; 3, neither disagree nor agree; 4, agree; and 5, strongly agree). Physicians were asked to identify themselves as attending physician or as a fellow. Nurses were asked to identify their primary work unit (medical ICU, surgical ICU, or medical–surgical ICU) and to report their proficiency level using the Dreyfus Model of Skill Acquisition (novice, advanced beginner, competent, proficient, and expert).22

sec.title: Data Collection
sec.p: A survey packet was mailed to all participants. The packet contained the survey, a preaddressed return envelope, and a cover letter explaining the survey. The survey was self-administered and anonymous. A duplicate mailing was sent to all participants 2 months after the first mailing in an attempt to maximize the response rate. Those who already participated were asked to disregard the second mailing. All responses received 3 months after the initial mailing were included in the analysis.

sec.title: Data Analysis
sec.p: The primary analysis of this study was to compare survey responses to each of the 12 items among physicians and nurses. In addition, physicians’ responses were compared by dividing this group into attending physicians and fellows. Nurses’ responses were compared by work unit and self-reported proficiency level.

Statistical tests were computed for each survey item separately. Wilcoxon rank sum tests were used for comparisons between 2 groups (physicians vs nurses and attendings vs fellows). Kruskal-Wallis tests were used for comparisons with more than 2 groups (work units and self-reported proficiency levels). Statistical analysis was performed with JMP software (JMP, Version 5, SAS Institute Inc, Cary, North Carolina). A P value ≤ .05 was considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Demographics
sec.p: The survey was sent to 69 critical care physicians (48 attending physicians and 21 fellows) and 629 critical care nurses. In all, 50 physicians (72%) and 331 nurses (53%) returned the survey for the total response rate of 55% (386 of 698). Five surveys were returned without identification (physician or nurse) and were excluded from the analysis (Table 1).

Ninety-three percent (308 of 331) of nurse respondents reported their self-assessed level of proficiency. Thus, the nurses were divided into 10 novices, 43 advanced beginners, 51 competent nurses, 122 proficient nurses, and 82 experts. Fifty-one percent (165 of 331) of nurses reported their primary work unit. The nurses were grouped accordingly into medical (n = 45, 27%), surgical (n = 69, 41%) and mixed medical–surgical (n = 54, 32%) ICU work units (Table 2).

sec.title: Survey Instrument Scores
sec.p: Complete results for each of the 12 items are presented in Table 3. The primary analysis suggested significant differences in EOLC perspectives between physicians and nurses in 7 of 12 statements (statements 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 9, and 12). In each of the 7 statements showing a difference, physicians reported a higher level of agreement compared to nurses.

tr.td: 1. Fear of litigation often results in transferring dying patients to ICU
2. Patients and families are encouraged to make timely and appropriate decisions about DNR orders
3. Physicians talk about health care directives with patients and family members
4. A spiritual assessment is routinely placed in patients charts and nurses/physicians know about it
5. Bereavement and follow-up services are offered to family members of patients who died in the ICU
6. Services of a social worker are offered to dying patients and family members
7. Effective and timely pain management/comfort care is provided to patients who are dying
8. Appropriate patients are referred to hospice in a timely manner
9. I can safely raise questions and concerns about end-of-life care policies and practices
10. A patient’s death in the ICU reflects a medical failure
11. Caring for dying patients and their families is a rewarding experience
12. The ICU provides professional education to physicians to improve end-of-life clinical practices

fn.p: Abbreviations: ICU, intensive care unit; DNR, do not resuscitate.

sec.p: Analysis of secondary aims suggested differences between attending physicians and fellows in 2 statements (statements 1 and 12), differences among ICU nurses based on their primary work unit in 3 statements (Statements 3, 5, and 6), and differences among ICU nurses based on their self-reported proficiency levels in 5 statements (statements 1, 2, 3, 11, and 12). The statistically significant differences among each group are presented in Table 4.

caption.p: Differences Between Critical Care Physicians and Nurses Regarding EOLC

list-item.p:
Statement 1: Fear of litigation often results in transferring dying patients to ICU
Fellows were more likely to agree than attending physicians (P = .003)
Novice nurses were more likely to agree than expert nurses (P < .001)

Statement 2: Patients and families are encouraged to make timely and appropriate decisions about DNR orders
Physicians were more likely to agree than nurses (P = .003)
Novice nurses were more likely to agree than more expert nurses (P = .014)

Statement 3: Physicians talk about health care directives with patient and family members
Physicians were more likely to agree than nurses (P < .001)
Novice nurses were more likely to agree than expert nurses (P < .005)
Nurses from a medical ICU were more likely to agree than from a surgical ICU (P = .02)

Statement 4: A spiritual assessment is routinely placed in patients charts and nurses/physicians know about it
Physicians were more likely to agree than nurses (P < .001)

Statement 5: Bereavement and follow-up services are offered to family members of patients who died in the ICU
Nurses from a medical ICU were more likely to agree than from a surgical ICU (P < .001)

Statement 6: Services of a social worker are offered to dying patients and family members
Physicians were more likely to agree than nurses (P < .001)
Nurses from a surgical ICU were more likely to agree than from a medical ICU (P = .018)

Statement 7: Effective and timely pain management/comfort care is provided to patients who are dying
No differences.

Statement 8: Appropriate patients are referred to hospice in a timely manner
Physicians were more likely to agree than nurses (P = .047)

Statement 9: I can safely raise questions and concerns about end-of-life care policies and practices
Physicians were more likely to agree than nurses (P < .001)

Statement 10: A patient’s death in the ICU reflects a medical failure
No differences.

Statement 11: Caring for dying patients and their families is a rewarding experience
Expert nurses were more likely to agree than novice nurses (P = .01)

Statement 12: The ICU provides professional education to physicians to improve end-of-life clinical practices
Physicians were more likely to agree than nurses (P = .018)
Novice nurses were more likely to agree than expert nurses (P < .001)
Fellows were more likely to agree than attending physicians (P = .016)

fn.p: Abbreviations: EOLC, end-of-life care; ICU, intensive care unit; DNR, do not resuscitate.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Our goal was to explore the perspectives of critical care physicians and nurses regarding EOLC in the ICU, with a focus on how these perspectives are influenced by level of ICU experience and work unit. Our results demonstrate that while there is much agreement between physicians and nurses, many important areas of disagreement exist. Our results also suggest that differences exist among physicians based on experience (attending staff physicians vs fellows), as well as among nurses based on their primary work unit and self-reported proficiency level.

We identified 5 areas of difference between the EOLC assessments of nurses and physicians. We found that nurses felt that they were unable to safely voice concerns regarding EOLC policies and practices, while physicians felt more comfortable in doing so. This finding has been documented in previous studies.7,23 Possible reasons why nurses may feel unable to voice concerns include a history of harsh criticism when attempting to do so and a feeling that their opinion does not matter to either the physicians or the family.23 Nurses are an essential component of the teamwork necessary to provide quality EOLC. Improving nurses’ ability to safely voice concern in delivering quality EOLC represents a significant area for improvement.

Additionally, we found that physicians were more likely to agree than nurses that appropriate and timely discussions regarding health care directives and do not resuscitate (DNR) orders were taking place. Prior studies have suggested that nurses were more willing than physicians to withdraw life support, especially in patient populations at significant risk of imminent death.24 The factors that may impede physicians from making timely DNR decisions have not yet been fully elucidated.

Physicians were more likely than nurses to agree that spiritual assessments were completed and that members of the medical team were aware of such assessments. Addressing spiritual needs is a core component of providing quality EOLC.25 Thus, it is necessary for ICU providers to obtain competence in providing care to patients of differing cultures, religions, and beliefs.26–28 The documented differences between physicians and nurses in this area emphasize the need for further intervention and education regarding spiritual assessments.

Many reasons have been proposed to explain both the discrepancies between physicians and nurses, as well as the consistently higher levels of satisfaction reported by physicians. First, both physicians and nurses perceive that nurses have minimal, if any real participation in end-of-life decision making.9,29,30 A perceived lack of impact may be a source for dissatisfaction among nurses. Second, nurses often perceive that conflicting information and opinions are given to patients and their families by various physicians caring for the same patient.31–33 Third, a lack of communication may also contribute to dissatisfaction among nurses.34,35 Fourth, when presented with a patient scenario, ICU nurses seem to experience higher levels of moral stress as compared to physicians. In one study, 45% of nurses considered leaving a position secondary to moral stress, compared to only 3% of physicians.10 Nurses also spend more time with patients and may be more acutely aware of suffering.36,37 Further contributing factors may include differences in authority, education, and work philosophies.38 Each of these causes of discrepancy represents an opportunity for intervention.

Disagreement between nurses and physicians has been associated with impaired quality of EOLC, and may be an indicator that one or more needs of the patient is not being met. Additional outcomes such as poor comprehension, anxiety, and depression have been reported when successful physician and nurse collaboration is absent.21

Besides finding differences, we also noted important areas of agreement between physicians and nurses. Almost no physicians or nurses thought that a patient’s death in the ICU reflects a medical failure. Most physicians and nurses thought that caring for dying patients and their families was a rewarding experience. This was present despite the above listed sources of dissatisfaction. Agreement may be secondary to recent institutional efforts to provide comprehensive EOLC training to physicians.39

Attitudes of physicians and nurses regarding EOLC evolve with training and experience.40–42 This may reflect the fact that one of the best methods of learning to provide quality EOLC is through experience. It may also reflect the fact that ICU providers are forced to learn to provide quality EOLC through experience because many programs do not contain formal training on EOLC43 and many medical textbooks do not sufficiently address the topic.44 Indeed significant agreement among fellows and attending physicians in all areas of EOLC may reflect the implementation of formal EOLC education in our institution.39

Prior studies have noted differences based on work unit.45,46 One study suggested that satisfaction was highest in the medical ICU, lower in medical–surgical ICU, and lowest in the surgical ICU.9 Our survey also suggests that differences exist between nurses working in medical, surgical, and medical–surgical ICUs. These particular results warrant cautious interpretation because only 51% of nurses who returned surveys identified their primary work unit assignment. This was a surprising finding and may suggest a desire for increased anonymity among nurses. Evidence for increased anonymity may in part be correlated with the perception discussed above that nurses are less likely to feel comfortable voicing concerns.

An important limitation of our study is that we tested only the perceptions of providers, not the actual practices of providing EOLC in the ICU. We did not test for possible confounding variables such as gender, age, ethnicity, administrative models, or social factors. Other limitations of this study include recall bias, a total response rate of 55%, closed-ended statements, and the lack of knowledge of level of test–retest reliability. The applicability of these results may be limited based on the fact that they came from a single, academic, tertiary care medical center in the Midwest region of the United States.

In conclusion, we identified important differences among critical care physicians and nurses with respect to EOLC in the ICU. We identified additional differences based on experience level and work unit (medical vs surgical ICU). Physicians continue to report higher satisfaction of EOLC in the ICU than nurses. These differences may represent significant barriers toward providing comprehensive, consistent, and coordinated EOLC in the ICU, and as such are potential targets for further research and quality improvement efforts.

fn.p: Author contributions: Study concept and design: Festic, Divertie, Rabatin. Analysis and interpretation of data: Festic, Wilson, Gajic, Divertie, Rabatin. Drafting of the manuscript: Festic, Wilson, Rabatin. Critical revision of the manuscript for important intellectual content: Festic, Wilson, Gajic, Divertie, Rabatin. Statistical analysis: Festic, Wilson, Gajic. Study supervision: Festic, Gajic, Rabatin.
The author(s) declared no conflicts of interest with respect to the authorship and/or publication of this article.
The author(s) disclosed receipt of the following financial support for the research and/or authorship of this article: Mayo Clinic and Mayo Foundation.
